label: Folder 01: Gibbes Finding Aid
description: Description and index of Civic Services Committee materials that were taken from Carolina Art Association and incorporated into the files of what became Historic Charleston Foundation.  Also includes a list of materials "now on deposit at SC Historical Society," and the finding aid to the Civic Services Committee records that are still held at the Gibbes Museum of Art.

metadata.label: Description

Also includes a list of materials "now on deposit at SC Historical Society," and the finding aid to the Civic Services Committee records that are still held at the Gibbes Museum of Art.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
GIBBES MUSEUM OF ART  135 MEETING STREET, Charleston SOUTH Carolina   29401  Civic Services Committee records, 1941-1946  Brief Description of collection  Tite: Civic Services Committee records, 1941-1946  Creator: Civic Services Committee of the Carolina Art  Association  Accession Number: A013.00  Extent Size: 1 Document case  ocation: See Archives Shef isting  Administrative Information  Provenance: When forma space was estabished for archiva materias in 1996 these  materias were gathered from various record storage areas in the museum buiding, these  materias were ikey stored in the defunct ibrary or on the unfinished 3rd foor storage  area.  Access Restrictions: Unprocessed materias are cosed pending processing  ega Status Copyright Information: Copyright for official Museum documents is  held by the Gibbes Museum of Art; a other copyright is retained by the authors of items  in these papers, or their descendants, as stipuated by United States copyright  Preferred Citation: Gibbes Museum of Art Archives  Archivists Processing Notes:  historical Notes  The Civic Services Committee, sponsored by the Carolina Art Associaltion, was formay  organized in the spring of 1940. Organizing members of the committee incuded, E.  Miby Burton, John Mead Howes, James O"Hear, Homer M. place, Sidney J. Rittenberg,  Albert Simons, Alice R.H. Smith, Samuel G. Stoney and Robert N. S. Whitelaw. The  committee was organized to study the need for practical preservation and planned  growth. The Committee received grant funding from the Rockefeller Foundation and the  Carnegie Corporation. Funds were used to secure a piot study of the city by Frederick  aw Olmstead Jr. and to compie a comprehensive inventory the city"s architecture which  resuted in the Publication "This is Charleston". Additionay the committee sponsored  studies of community growth and proposed a downtown traffic and parking plan.  Scope and Content  This collection consists of the records of the Civic Services Committee formed under the  Carolina Art  Association in 1940. The collection incudes minutes and associated  materias, memoranda, reports, correspondence, artices, speeches, pamphets, press 

[End Page 1]
clippings, and other records of the Civic Services Committee and reated organizations.  Materias range in date from 1941-1946.  Series Description Container isting  Box 1  folders:  Civic Services Committee, minutes, 1942-1946 [3 folders]  Charleston regional planning Committee, minutes, 1942  Carolina Art  Association Executive Board, minutes, 1942-1946  Correspondence, 1942, 1943  Press clippings, 1944, n.d.  Report of the Charleston regional planning Committee, n.d.  Post War planning in Charleston, n.d.  Off Street Parking, 1945  Civic Services Committee Work and Objectives, Pamphet, 1944 [incudes objectives  by Frederick aw Olmstead Jr.]  This is Charleston, exhibition records, 1942  "An architectural Inventory of Charleston", artice by Helen McCormack, American  Society of architectural History, Vo I, No. 3-4, Juy - Oct. 1941  Community development Counci, 1943  Robert N.S. Whitelaw, speech, 1942  Robert N.S. Whitelaw, "planning Charleston Past and Present" speech, 1942  Civic Services Committee, Rockefeller Foundation, grant request, 1942 

[End Page 2]
